Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Offer help or support when asked
Situation2: The acquaintance's car has broken down on a quiet road, and they are calling for assistance.
Story: I was sitting at the dinner table with my stepfamily, half-listening as they tossed around ideas for the weekend. My stepdad wanted us all to go hiking, and my stepsister was excitedly suggesting a picnic. I knew they expected me to join in, to be part of the family, to show that I cared about these moments together. Just as I was about to chime in, my phone buzzed. It was a message from Jamie, an acquaintance from my college class. Her car had broken down on a quiet road outside town, and she was asking if I could come help her out. I could almost hear the anxiety in her text, and I knew she didn’t have anyone else nearby to call. I looked up at my stepfamily, their faces bright with anticipation, waiting for my input. My phone vibrated again in my hand. I felt torn—should I be the reliable step-sibling they wanted, or the supportive acquaintance Jamie needed? The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I sat frozen, caught between two worlds, unsure which one I was supposed to choose.
